Literature Review: The study of ocean circulation patterns and connectivity between the Arctic and North Atlantic Oceans has been significantly enhanced by the use of anthropogenic radionuclides as tracers. These radionuclides, primarily released from European nuclear fuel reprocessing plants, have provided valuable insights into water circulation, mixing, ventilation, and deep-water formation processes in these critical regions. This literature review aims to explore the evolution and current state of research utilizing nuclear reprocessing tracers to illuminate flow features and connectivity between the Arctic and Subpolar North Atlantic Oceans.Early tracer studies predominantly focused on 137Cs, which played a crucial role in revealing some of the first significant insights into Arctic Ocean circulation. Smith et al. (1998) demonstrated the utility of 137Cs in tracking the movement of Atlantic-derived waters into the Arctic Ocean, providing evidence for the circulation of Atlantic Layer water within the Arctic basins. This work laid the foundation for subsequent studies using radionuclide tracers to investigate Arctic Ocean dynamics.As analytical techniques advanced, particularly with the development of accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS), researchers began to utilize long-lived radionuclide tracers such as 129I and 236U. These isotopes offer several advantages over 137Cs, including longer half-lives and more conservative behavior in seawater. Alfimov et al. (2004) pioneered the use of 129I as a tracer for Arctic Ocean circulation, demonstrating its potential to provide time-integrated information on water mass movement and mixing.The application of 129I as a tracer has since been extensively developed, with numerous studies leveraging its unique properties to investigate various aspects of Arctic and North Atlantic circulation. For instance, Karcher et al. (2012) used 129I measurements in combination with numerical modeling to trace the pathways of Atlantic Water in the Arctic Ocean, revealing complex circulation patterns and estimating transit times between different regions. Their work highlighted the importance of integrating observational data with modeling approaches to gain a comprehensive understanding of ocean dynamics.Building upon these efforts, recent studies have increasingly employed multiple tracer approaches to provide more robust and detailed insights into circulation patterns. Smith et al. (2011) combined measurements of 129I and 236U to investigate the transport of Atlantic-derived waters into the Canada Basin, demonstrating the complementary nature of these tracers in elucidating water mass origins and mixing processes. This multi-tracer approach has become increasingly common, allowing researchers to overcome limitations associated with individual tracers and provide more comprehensive assessments of ocean circulation.The development and application of advanced modeling techniques have further enhanced the utility of radionuclide tracer data. Orre et al. (2010) utilized the North Atlantic–Arctic Ocean–Sea Ice Model (NAOSIM) in conjunction with 129I observations to simulate the dispersion of this tracer throughout the Arctic and North Atlantic. Their work demonstrated the power of combining observational data with high-resolution numerical models to improve our understanding of complex circulation patterns and water mass transformations.More recently, the incorporation of transit time distributions (TTDs) into tracer studies has allowed for more precise characterization of mixing processes and water mass ages. Rudels et al. (2012) applied TTD analysis to 129I data in the Arctic Ocean, providing new insights into the ventilation of deep waters and the timescales of water mass renewal. This approach has proven particularly valuable in regions with complex mixing dynamics, such as the Arctic Ocean and Nordic Seas.The application of nuclear reprocessing tracers has also contributed significantly to our understanding of deep-water formation processes in the North Atlantic. Vivo-Vilches et al. (2018) used 129I and 236U measurements to investigate the formation and spreading of North Atlantic Deep Water, demonstrating the utility of these tracers in tracking the movement of newly formed deep waters and estimating formation rates. Their work highlighted the importance of these processes in the context of global thermohaline circulation and climate.As climate change continues to impact the Arctic and North Atlantic regions, the use of radionuclide tracers has become increasingly important for monitoring and understanding these changes. Casacuberta et al. (2016) utilized 129I and 236U to investigate the impact of increased freshwater input on Arctic Ocean circulation, demonstrating the potential of these tracers to detect and quantify changes in water mass distributions and mixing patterns.In conclusion, the use of nuclear reprocessing tracers has significantly advanced our understanding of flow features and connectivity between the Arctic and Subpolar North Atlantic Oceans. From early studies using 137Cs to recent multi-tracer approaches incorporating 129I and 236U, these radionuclides have provided valuable insights into ocean circulation, mixing, and ventilation processes. The integration of observational data with advanced modeling techniques and transit time distribution analysis has further enhanced the utility of these tracers, contributing to a more comprehensive understanding of the complex dynamics governing these critical ocean regions. As climate change continues to impact high-latitude ocean systems, the ongoing development and application of radionuclide tracer techniques will play a crucial role in monitoring and understanding these changes, with important implications for global thermohaline circulation and climate.
